results.title: Sunrise at midnight
results.creator_credit: Sean O'Brien, Sophie Jackson, Australian Film Commission and Australia Council
results.brief_description: Sunrise at midnight is both a documentary portrait of Yumi Umiumare, a contemporary Japanese/Australian butoh dancer, and a Japanese Ghost story set in the Australian Desert. The film is inspired by an historic photograph of a troupe of Japanese female performers who toured outback towns at the turn of the century, and the tale of one such performer, Noriko, who wandered into the desert and never came back. Filmmaker Sean O’Brien and butoh Dancer Yumi Umiumare make an expedition into the desert to experience and exorcise Noriko’s lost soul. Performed by Yumi Umiumare and Tony Yap; original music by Satsuki Odamura and Anne Norman. An elegiac and graceful work, filmed on location in Far Western New South Wales.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Sean O’Brien, Sophie Jackson, Australian Film Commission and Australia Council

results.title: Sunrise = 日出
results.creator_credit: Wan Fang, Cao Yu, Yang Gongmin, Yu Benzheng and Shanghai Film Studios
results.brief_description:
Chen Bailu is an innocent young lady, compelled by the harsh reality she is forced into, becoming a social butterfly lost among the Shanghai nightclubs. She spends her days circulating amongst the wealthiest tycoons such as Pan Yueting and Zhang George, living a luxurious and voluptuous life style. The sudden arrival of Bailu’s past sweetheart arouses her memories of a simpler life and the longing for a new beginning. She views her world with disgust and contempt, yet she no longer has the power to break away from her extravagant life style.

One day, Bailu rescues a little girl who is ready to be sold into a low-class brothel and names her “little thing”. Due to the sympathetic feelings towards the likeliness of their fates, Bailu claims the little girl as her daughter and uses all her power to protect “little thing”. However, “little thing” does not escape her fate of forced prostitution, even with the help from the good hearted prostitute Cui Xi, the unbearable insult eventually driving “little thing” into suicide.

At the same time, Bailu’s wealthy lover Pan Yueting loses all his money by going against the underworld mafia’s Jin Ba and is on the verge of bankruptcy, leading Bailu into accumulating piles of heavy debts she cannot pay for. Bailu loses all hope for life when she finally learns her debts are been taken care of by Jin Ba, meaning her ownership has been transferred. In her final moments, she looks back to “little thing” and Cui Xi and refuses to exist as a puppet of upper society. She silently swallows some sleeping pills and ends her life.
(Wendy Xu, 2013).
results.creator_credit_for_label: Wan Fang, Cao Yu, Yang Gongmin, Yu Benzheng and Shanghai Film Studios

results.title: Sunpower
results.creator_credit: Dan Bessie, Barr Films and Shire Films
results.brief_description: An animated film tracing the history of our knowledge about the sun, also showing the ways in which the earth is dependent on the sun. The use of solar energy, emphasizing the power potential of the sun is also described.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Dan Bessie, Barr Films and Shire Films

results.title: Sunny munchy crunchy natural food shop
results.creator_credit: Richard Todd, David Bairstow and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: If you are a health food buff, this film is for you. Even if you are not, there is still enough in it to tickle your fancy, perhaps strain your credulity. The camera scans shelves stocked with all manner of natural foods to which nary an additive has been added - soya bean and sesame seed products, wild honey, even eggs from hens fed on blackstrap molasses. But the real eye-openers are in what you hear from the store’s proprietor and his customers. (Award: Berlin.)

results.title: Sunny Iceland: land of the vikings
results.brief_description: Shows the life of the people of barren but surprisingly warm Iceland: the green-houses which use hot springs; and the major industries, fishing and whaling.

results.title: Sunny and the dark horse
results.creator_credit: David MacDougall, Judith MacDougall and AIAS Film Unit
results.brief_description: This is a companion to the documentaries ‘Stockman’s Strategy’ and ‘Collum Calling Canberra’. Sunny Bancroft, the Aboriginal manager of a co-operative cattle station in northern New South Wales is the central ‘character’ in what is the most narratively-oriented of the trilogy. We follow Sunny as he indulges his passion for horses by acquiring and training a galloper for the picnic races.

results.title: Sunless = Sans Soleil
results.brief_description: An unknown woman reads and comments upon letters she receives from a friend, a freelance cameraman who travels around the world. The cameraman asks himself, and his colleagues, what is the point of describing the world like this when he is always its instrument, and what part does memory, which he helps to create, play?

results.title: Sunfruit
results.creator_credit: Artransa Park Studios and Jackson Wain
results.brief_description: Records a visit by a school group to a pineapple farm in Queensland. Shows the harvesting and processing of pineapples, and provides information about the planting and development of the fruit. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: Sunflowers
results.creator_credit: Larry Gosnell and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: At the Manitoba Experimental Farm, Julian Biggs interviews the plant breeder who is experimenting with sunflowers adapted to grow in prairie conditions.

results.title: Sunflowers
results.creator_credit: Ian McMillan and British Film Institute
results.brief_description: An experimental film which admirably exploits the photogenic qualities of sunflowers. After a poetic opening a rapid montage of images links the flowers with the processes of birth, life and death,
